title: German submarine U-94 (1940)
text:
German submarine "U-94" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during World War II. She was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 9 September 1939 at the F. Krupp "<a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a>" in <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> as yard number 599, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 12 June 1940 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 10 August 1940 under "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" <a href="Herbert%20Kuppisch">Herbert Kuppisch</a>.
She sank 26 ships of in ten patrols and was a member of six <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s but was herself sunk by a US aircraft and a Canadian warship on 28 August 1942.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-94" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="AEG">AEG</a> GU 460/8–27 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-94" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%26amp%3Bnbsp%3Bcm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
First patrol.
The boat left Kiel on 20 November 1940, heading for <a href="Lorient">Lorient</a> in France which she reached, via the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> on 31 December.
On the way, she sank "Stirlingshire" on 2 December, northwest of the <a href="Bloody%20Foreland">Bloody Foreland</a>, (a northwesterly point of the Irish mainland).
She also sent "Wilhelmina" and "Empire Statesman" to the bottom on the second and the 11th respectively.
After that, the boat headed for mid-ocean before docking at her French Atlantic base.
Second and third patrols.
"U-94" returned to the Atlantic west of Ireland and Scotland for her second patrol. She sank three more ships: on 20 January 1941, "West Wales" on the 29th and "Rushpool" on the 30th.
For her third sortie, the boat moved into the waters west of <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>. She sank "Harbledown" on 4 April 1941 and "Lincoln Ellsworth" on the sixth. The latter ship was destroyed by a combination of <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> and fire from the <a href="deck%20gun">deck gun</a>.
Fourth and fifth patrols.
"U-94" was attacked by the escorts of <a href="convoy%20OB%20318">convoy OB 318</a> on 7 May 1941. Some 98 <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s over four hours were dropped. The boat persisted with her attack, however, sinking "Eastern Star" and "Ixion".
Two more merchantmen met their end on the 20th: "Norman Monarch" and "John P. Pedersen".
Patrol number five was carried out west of the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a>; it was relatively uneventful.
Sixth patrol.
Having left St. Nazaire on 2 September 1941, "U-94" operated southeast of <a href="Cape%20Farewell%2C%20Greenland">Cape Farewell</a> (<a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>). She sank "Newbury", "Pegasus" and "Empire Eland", all on the 15th. On 1 October, she fired five torpedoes at "San Florentino". Three of them struck home; the ship broke in two after the third impact. The bow section remained afloat and was engaged by the U-boat's deck gun, it was eventually finished off by .
The boat returned to Kiel on 15 October.
Seventh patrol.
"U-94" departed Kiel on 12 January 1942; she negotiated the <a href="GIUK%20gap">gap</a> between the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe</a> and <a href="Shetland%20Islands">Shetland Islands</a>, docking once more at St. Nazaire on the 30th.
Eighth patrol.
The U-boat continued her successes on the western side of the Atlantic. She sank the "Empire Hail" east of <a href="St.%20John%27s%2C%20Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">St. Johns</a>, <a href="Newfoundland%20%28island%29">Newfoundland</a> on 24 February 1942. Following the coast-line to the south, her next victim was "Cayrú", about from New York on 9 March. She also sank "Hvoslef" two miles east of <a href="Fenwick%20Island%2C%20Delaware">Fenwick Island</a>, off <a href="Delaware%20Bay">Delaware Bay</a> on the 11th.
Ninth patrol.
"U-94" left St. Nazaire on 4 May 1942 for what would be her top-scoring patrol, (it was to be carried out once more south of Greenland). Moving into this area, a steady stream of sinkings resulted; the "Cocle" on 12 May, "Batna" and "Tolken", both on the 13th - a sailing ship, "Maria da Glória" on 5 June; "Ramsay" and "<a href="Empire%20Clough">Empire Clough</a>" on the tenth. Her last kill was "Pontypridd", on the following day.
Tenth patrol and loss.
The boat left St. Nazaire for the last time for the <a href="Caribbean%20Sea">Caribbean</a> on 3 August 1942. Off <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a> on the 28th, she was sunk by depth charges dropped by a US <a href="PBY%20Catalina">PBY Catalina</a> from <a href="VPB-92">VP-92</a> and ramming by the Canadian corvette .
Nineteen men died with the U-boat; there were twenty-six survivors.
Wolfpacks.
"U-94" took part in six <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s, namely:
